response.answer_text: The ending of the slave trade ended in England in 1807 although the emancipation of those already in slavery in the carribean did not start till 1823 whearas the us northern states banned slavery in 1808 they did not have slaves so they didn’t fee any slaves directly although those escaping to the north could claim their freedom. It wasn’t until 1865 with the 13th amendment that slavery officially ended in the us as a whole.

Britain had few slaves in the United Kingdom itself. There were doubts about its legality at home, with some old cases saying it was not. Their issue was ending slavery in their colonies in the Caribbean and Africa, which they handled by raising a huge amount of money to pay off the owners. That is the Slavery Abolition Act of 1833. Half was paid directly to British slave owners in Africa and the Caribbean, half to their owners living in Britain. That’s 20 million pounds, about 15 million borrowed. And it was mostly paid to the wealthy and well-connected. They did not include slaves owned in places like Ceylon.
It was only 30 years earlier,not ages as they give out.
An act of parliament and enforcement against the slave trade at sea. No official laws limiting the rights of ‘blacks in the terminology of the time. USA about thirty five years later. Jim crow.
